DSS_METRIC_DESCRIPTIONS.METRIC_DESCRIPTION: Avoid Artifacts with High Cyclomatic Complexity (HTML5/Javascript)

The effort and time for diagnosis of deficiencies or causes of failures, or for identification of parts to be modified is directly related to the number of execution paths, i.e. the complexity of the control flow. Analyzability declines with increasing Cyclomatic Complexity. Each modification must be correct for all execution paths. Cyclomatic Complexity computes the number of the linearly independent paths, a lower bound of all execution paths ignoring multiple iterations. Changeability declines with increasing Cyclomatic Complexity. Complete testing requires coverage of all execution paths. Cyclomatic Complexity computes the number of the linearly independent paths, a lower bound of all execution paths ignoring multiple iterations. Testability declines with increasing Cyclomatic Complexity.

Avoid Artifacts with High Cyclomatic Complexity (CC > 20). Complex Artifacts are difficult to maintain. Keeping Artifacts small and simple ensures an good readability of the code. The threshold level is a parameter that can be changed at will.
Review the design of the Artifact to reduce number of independent paths. E.g.: Reduce the number of conditional statements.
Associated to each HTML5/Javascript Artifact with violations, the Quality Rule provides: - The Cyclomatic complexity
Number of HTML5/Javascript Artifacts
Cyclomatic complexity
Avoid programs with low comment / code ratio (HTML5/Javascript)
Maintainability of the code is facilitated if there is documentation in the code. This rule will ensure there are comments within the program.
This rule searches all the programs having a low comment/code ratio.
Try to increase the comment/code ratio for programs.
The report lists all the unreferenced HTML5/Javascript Programs It provides following information: - program name
Number of HTML5/Javascript Programs
Comment/code ratio
Avoid using querySelectorAll
Ensure your web application interactivity by accessing/manipulating the DOM tree with high performance queries/enumerators.
Compared to getElementsByTagName and getElementsByClassName, querySelectorAll can be 40 time slower.
Instead of using querySelectorAll, you will use getElementsByTagName() or getElementsByClassName().
[1] http://www.infoq.com/presentations/JavaScript-Performance-Patterns [2] http://jsperf.com/queryinging/4 OMG CISQ ASCPEM-PRF-4
var trs = tabtab.querySelectorAll('.rowme');
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Javascript Functions
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid calling a function in a termination loop (Javascript)
When calling a function in a end loop, the function will be computed for each loop iteration and will decrease dramatically performances.
Reports all JavaScript code that call a function in a loop termination.
Use a variable to store the result of a function and use it as the loop termination.
AJAX in Action - Manning - ISBN 1-932394-61-3 page 290 CISQ OMG
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Javascript Functions
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using for-in loop
Ensure your web application interactivity by accessing/manipulating the DOM tree with high performance queries/enumerators.

Since each iteration through the loop results in a property lookup either on the instance or on a prototype, the for-in loop has considerably more overhead per iteration and is therefore slower than the other loops. For the same number of loop iterations, a for-in loop can end up as much as seven times slower than the other loop types. For this reason, it's recommended to avoid the for-in loop unless your intent is to iterate over an unknown number of object properties.
Replace the for-in with regular for with index
CISQ OMG ASCPEM-PRF-4
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Javascript Functions
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using forEach()
Ensure your web application interactivity by accessing/manipulating the DOM tree with high performance queries/enumerators.

Even though function-based iteration represents a more convenient method of iteration, it is also quite a bit slower than loop-based iteration. The slowdown can be accounted for by the overhead associated with an extra method being called on each array item. In all cases, function-based iteration takes up to eight times as long as loop-based iteration and therefore isn’t a suitable approach when execution time is a significant concern.
Use the regular for loop to enumerate the array
CISQ OMG ASCPEM-PRF-4 http://jsperf.com/foreach-vs-loop
arr.forEach(function(v){v;}); // BAD
for(var i = 0, l = arr.length; i < l; i++){arr[i];} // GOOD
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Javascript Functions
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using a web service with WebSocket inside a loop

When designing web service to get/put/post data, you want to make sure that you minimize the number of calls between the client application and web service server. By minimizing the number of calls, you improve application speed, reduce communications overhead (why send three request when you can do it by one), and reduce network traffic.

When designing web service to get/post/put data, you want to make sure that you minimize the number of calls between the client application and web service server. This rule will check the official WebSocket syntax, to do call to web service.
Try to create a process queue that will manage all the requests with a limited number of concurrents requests. When a request callback has been managed a new request could be fired.
CISQ Rule: ASCPEM-PRF-08
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Javascript Functions using WebSocket
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using a web service with XMLHttpRequest inside a loop

When designing web service to get/put/post data, you want to make sure that you minimize the number of calls between the client application and web service server. By minimizing the number of calls, you improve application speed, reduce communications overhead (why send three request when you can do it by one), and reduce network traffic.

When designing web service to get/post/put data, you want to make sure that you minimize the number of calls between the client application and web service server. This rule will check the official XMLHttpRequest syntax, to do call to web service.
Try to create a process queue that will manage all the requests with a limited number of concurrents requests. When a request callback has been managed a new request could be fired.
CISQ Rule: ASCPEM-PRF-08
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Javascript Functions using XMLHttpRequest
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using too much dot notation in loop

Every time the interpreter encounters a dot character, it will look up the child variable against the parent. For example, var hourHand=myGrandFather.clock.hands.hour make three lookup. When used too much in a loop, dot notation can affect performance of a javascript function. Reducing the dotation usage can win 50% of the time consumed by this function. This rule is compliant with CISQ OMG ASCPEM-PRF-4 recommendation.
List all JavaScript file, HTML file or function that reference more than 2 times the same variable name with more than one dot.
Use intermediate variable to minimize the number of dot within the loop.
AJAX in Action - Manning - ISBN 1-932394-61-3 page 296
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Javascript Functions
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using Web SQL databases
OWASP Top Ten 2013 Category A6 - Sensitive Data Exposure OWASP Top Ten 2013 Category A9 - Using Components with Known Vulnerabilities

The Web SQL Database standard will never be officially supported. It was first formulated, then deprecated by the W3C and was only implemented in some browsers. (It is not supported in Firefox or IE.)
Further, the use of a Web SQL Database poses security concerns, since you only need its name to access such a database.
Do not use window.openDatabase syntax.
http://www.w3.org/TR/webdatabase/
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Javascript Functions
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid blocking page loading with synchronous Javascript import

When you include javascript under this form <script src="http://*.js">, you create a Single Point of Failure. Loading the script in this way is blocking all other download in the page and any element below the script are blocked from rendering. It is better to load the script asynchronously.
Reports any code which contains the instruction <script src="http://*.js"> in the html body block.
[1] http://www.infoq.com/presentations/JavaScript-Performance-Patterns [2] http://www.stevesouders.com/blog/2008/12/27/coupling-async-scripts/
<script src="http://*.js">

<script async="http://*.js">

// or

<script defer="http://*.js">
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of HTML Contents
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using submitted markup containing "form" and "formaction" attributes
An attacker can use the combination of form and formaction markups to use the form to do spam.
Do not allow uses to submit markup containing "form" and "formaction" attributes.
https://html5sec.org/#1
<form id="test"><button form="test" formaction="javascript:alert(1)">X</button></form> <form><button formaction="javascript:alert(1)">X</button></form>
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of HTML Contents
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using submit markup related to "form" with id attribute
An attacker can use a form to do spam emailing. Ensure the form markup does not contain id attribute.
Do not allow users to use submit markup related to "form" with id attribute.
https://html5sec.org/#1 http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/association-of-controls-and-forms.html#attr-fs-formaction
<form id="myid"><input type="submit" value="Submit"></form>
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of HTML Contents
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using autofocus and onfocus in submitted markup
Ensure you don't use html pattern that can give a way to execute code without user interaction.
Do not allow self-executing focus event via autofocus otherwise it will execute a command without no user interaction.
https://html5sec.org/#7 http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/association-of-controls-and-forms.html#autofocusing-a-form-control
<input onfocus=write(1) autofocus>
<input autofocus>
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of HTML Contents
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using autofocus and onblur in submitted markup
Ensure you don't use html pattern that can give a way to execute code without user interaction.
Do not allow self-executing blur event via autofocus otherwise it will execute a command without no user interaction.
https://html5sec.org/#8 http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/association-of-controls-and-forms.html#autofocusing-a-form-control
<input onblur=write(1) autofocus>
<input autofocus>
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of HTML Contents
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using javascript or expression in the CSS file
Ensure your css files will not get data from untrusted source.
You will have to ensure that URLs only start with "http" not "javascript" and that properties never start with "expression".
{ background-url : "javascript:alert(1)"; } // and all other URLs { text-size: "expression(alert('XSS'))"; } // only in IE
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of CSS Contents
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using video poster attributes in combination with javascript
Ensure you don't use html pattern that can give a way to execute code without user interaction.
Do not allow users to use video markup with poster attribute combined with javascript.
Make sure only relative URIs and correctly MIME-typed data URIs can be used for VIDEO poster attributes
https://html5sec.org/#10
<video poster=javascript:alert(1)//></video>
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of HTML Contents
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid hosting HTML code in iframe srcdoc
Ensure you do not have html pattern that allows an attacker to try an injection using iframe content features.

HTML5 specifies a "srcdoc" attribute for Iframes. This attribute, quite similar to data URIs, is capable of hosting HTML text to be rendered by the browser as the content of the Iframe. The pseudo-document created by the "srcdoc" attribute has full access to the hosting domain, although it runs in an artificial origin. This attribute should if at all only be used in combination with the Iframe Sandbox.
Make sure to use "srcdoc" only in combination with the Iframe Sandbox. Otherwise, XSS attacks might slip through existing filters rules as the payload can be HTML encoded.
https://html5sec.org/#139
<iframe srcdoc="<img src=x:x onerror=alert(1)>" />
<iframe sandbox srcdoc="<img src=x:x onerror=alert(1)>" />
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of HTML Contents
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using onscroll event with autofocus input
Ensure you don't use html pattern that can give a way to execute code without user interaction.
Do not allow users to use an autofocus on an input when onscroll event has been defined on the body. This pattern will create a self-executing javascript via body.
https://html5sec.org/#12
<body onscroll=alert(1)> ... .... <input autofocus> ... ... </body>
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of HTML Contents
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid defining and calling functions inside loops
Writing functions within loops tends to result in errors due to the way the function creates a closure around the loop.
Defining a function inside a loop is adding unnecessary steps and will certainly affect performance, this is why this rule will find all the javascript anonymous function call/creation in loops.
Define the function out of the loop and use the reference inside the loop
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Closures http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-loop-func
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of anonymous javascript function call in loops
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using delete with no object properties
ASCMM-MNT-20

Because the semantics of the delete operator are a bit tricky, and it can only be reliably used to remove properties from objects. Pass anything else to it, and you may or may not get the desired result.
http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-delete-var
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of HTML Contents
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid having iframe inside a tag
Ensure you do not have html pattern that allows an attacker to do a reverse clickjacking.

This is a reverse clickjacking via iframe issue. For example, Internet Explorer allows to place <IFRAME> tags inside <A> tags. By clicking on a not clickable element inside the IFRAME there will be executed the URL defined in the "href" attribute of the <A> tag.
https://html5sec.org/#117
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of HTML Contents
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using setData in ondragstart with attribute draggable set to true
Ensure you do not have html pattern that allows an attacker to try a text injection using drag and drop features.
This is a text injection by drag-and-drop. If you have a draggable block which triggered an ondragstart event that contains a malicious code and an iframe, the malicious code could be executed.
https://www.w3.org/html/wg/spec/dnd.html#dnd https://html5sec.org/#118
Drop me

Avoid using oninput in body containing input autofocus
Ensure you don't use html pattern that can give a way to execute code without user interaction.

This is a passive JavaScript execution via <BODY> and oninput attribute. All browsers besides Internet Explorer 9 support the "oninput" event handler around form elements like the given <INPUT>. The event works for the form elements itself, the surrounding form and <BODY> as well as <HTML> tags.
https://html5sec.org/#86
<body oninput=alert(1)> ... <input autofocus> ... </body>

Avoid using source tag in video/audio with event handler
Ensure you don't use html pattern that can give a way to execute code without user interaction.
Opera 10.5+ and Chrome allow error handlers in <SOURCE> tags if encapsulated by a <VIDEO> or <AUDIO> tag.
Make sure user submitted <SOURCE>, <AUDIO>, <VIDEO> tags cannot contain event handlers or whitelist event handlers necessary for UI controls
https://html5sec.org/#55 https://html5sec.org/#56
<video><source onerror="alert(1)"/></video> <video onerror="alert(1)"><source></source></video>

Avoid white-listing the "dirname" attribute in user generated content
Ensure you do not import content from an untrusted source.

Opera and Chrome support the HTML5 attribute "dirname", that can be used to have the browser communicate the text-flow direction of another input element by adding it to the server-sent request body. By injecting a "dirname" attribute in an existing form, an attacker can overwrite user input and thereby make it guessable for malicious purposes.
https://html5sec.org/#136

<form action="" method="post"> <input name="username" value="admin" /> <input name="password" type="password" value="secret" /> <input name="injected" value="injected" dirname="password" /> <input type="submit"> </form>
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code

Avoid using import with external URI
Ensure you do not import content from an untrusted source.

JavaScript could be executed via cross-origin HTML imports. Make sure that HTML imports are limited to the same origin. Avoid permitting users to have <link> tags in user-generated rich-text as they can now directly execute JavaScript without any user interaction.

Make sure that HTML imports are limited to the same origin. Avoid permitting users to have <link> tags in user-generated rich-text as they can now directly execute JavaScript without any user interaction.
https://html5sec.org/#138
<link rel="import" href="http://xxxx.com/test.svg" /> <!-- This may be not the current origin -->
<link rel="import" href="test.svg" />

Avoid using delete on arrays
ASCMM-MNT-20

The delete operator can be used to remove a property from any object. Arrays are objects, so the delete operator can be used here too, but if it is, a hole will be left in the array because the indexes/keys won't be shifted to reflect the deletion. Use the following methods to: - add/remove elements from the the array : Array.prototype.splice - add/remove elements from the end of the array : Array.prototype.pop - add/remove elements from the beginning of the array : Array.prototype.shift
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code

Avoid using Javascript Document.all collection
Using the Document.all collection is slow when retrieving its different objects into HTML, JS files as it collects - and loads in memory - all items.
Avoid using Javascript Document.all. This is a non-standard way of accessing DOM elements. It's been deprecated from a few browsers. It gives you access to all sub elements on your document.
Use the official method document.getElementById()
document.all['foo'].innerText = "Hello"
var temp = document.getElementById('foo'); temp.innerText = "Hello"

Avoid using eval() (Javascript)
The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes code syntax before using the input in a dynamic evaluation call (e.g. "eval").
The eval() function is used to run text as code. In almost all cases, it should not be necessary to use it. Because it allows arbitrary code to be run, it also represents a security problem.
If possible, refactor your code so that it does not need to use eval() at all.
var value = eval('object.' + aProperty); // non compliant
var value = object[aProperty]; // compliant
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code

Avoid using console.log()

If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

The purpose of the rule is to detect the usage of console.log function. You can expose sensitive information, slowing down the browser or break workflow of websites if you let log statements in production code.
Do not use console.log in production code
https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2013-A6-Sensitive_Data_Exposure https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2017-A6-Sensitive_Data_Exposure
console.log('#someButton was clicked');

Avoid using non thread-safe Javascript singleton pattern
If singleton is invoked in a multi-threaded program, you could end up creating multiple instances of the class which will make the application unstable.
Singleton objects should use a thread-safe pattern for creating their shared instance.
Make sure that you have only one instance created in class constructor and it has been frozen to avoid any changes.
OMG CISQ

Avoid Superclass knowing Subclass (Javascript)

Referencing down the inheritance tree is against Object-Oriented coding practices. It is a way of having two-way inheritance between class and subclass. This is an indication of poor class design and class inheritance. Such practices increase the complexity of the application.

A Superclass is not allowed to have knowledge of one of its Subclasses. The Superclass has knowledge of the Subclass if the Superclass directly calls a Subclass-method, uses a Subclass-attribute or refers to the name of the Subclass.
Review the design of the Class hierarchy
CISQ rule: ASCRM-RLB-14.
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code

Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using Javascript Function constructor
Using the Function constructor to create functions is not recommended since it needs the function body as a string which may prevent some JS engine optimizations and can also cause other problems.

Each time […] the Function constructor is called on a string representing source code, the script engine must start the machinery that converts the source code to executable code. This is usually expensive for performance – easily a hundred times more expensive than a simple function call, for example. An exception will be made for Function('return this')(); . It is the best way to retrieve the global in both node and web with or without "use strict".
https://jsperf.com/function-vs-function/2 https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions
var f2 = new Function('var x = 1;console.log("2");');
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code

Avoid return statement in finally block (Javascript)

Care must be taken if completion of a try-catch block occurs as a result of executing a return. If a finally block also returns a value, then that return supersedes any previous return in the try-catch block. Also, if an exception was thrown in the try or catch blocks that was not caught, then execution of a return in the finally block prevents the exception from being thrown to the caller (because it is not possible for the caller to simultaneously evaluate the return and catch the exception). This is also valid for break or continue instructions.

Reports all methods that contain an abrupt in a finally block. An abrupt completion of a statement or block occurs when it throws an exception, executes a break or continues to an enclosing statement, or executes a return from the method.

OWASP http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Return_Inside_Finally_Block
CWE http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/584.html
CISQ OMG ASCMM-MNT-01 - Control Flow Transfer Control Element outside Switch Block

Avoid direct access to Database Tables in Javascript
Direct access to database Table prevents the control at the database level of accesses. E.g.: use of non-optimized query against the database.
Applications should not access directly database Tables
Create one or several dedicated modules to access database. Encapsulate in these modules the object storing pool of connections
CISQ rule: ASCPEM-PRF-9.

Avoid using setTimeout()
The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes code syntax before using the input in a dynamic evaluation call.
The setTimeout() function is used to run text as code. In almost all cases, it should not be necessary to use it. Because it allows arbitrary code to be run, it also represents a security problem.

The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes code syntax before using the input in a dynamic evaluation call.
The setInterval() function is used to run text as code. In almost all cases, it should not be necessary to use it. Because it allows arbitrary code to be run, it also represents a security problem.

http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/95.html https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2013-A1-Injection https://www.w3schools.com/js/js_best_practices.asp

Avoid undocumented Functions (Javascript)
Maintainability of the code is facilitated if there is documentation in the code. This rule will ensure there are comments within the Artifact.
Functions should be documented. This reports shows all functions with no comments.
Add comments into functions to explain what is their goal and how they work.
This rule lists all undocumented Functions. It provides following information: - Function full name
Number of Functions
Avoid unreferenced Functions (Javascript/HTML5)

Unreferenced code may be the symptom of Dead Code. Dead Code must be avoided as it makes source code less readable and increases the cost of the software maintenance.
Warning: Unreferenced code can also be the symptoms of missing code (code not included in the source code analysis).

Reports all Functions that are not referenced except main.
Notes: - JavaScript eventHandler are not taken in account. - PL/SQL stored procedures are taken in account.
Check if the Function is truly unnecessary. Remove Functions that are not used.
This report lists all unreferenced Functions It provides the following information: Function full name.
Number of functions
Avoid Functions having a very low Comment/Code ratio (Javascript)
Maintainability of the code is facilitated if there is documentation in the code. This rule will ensure there are comments within the Artifact
Functions should have at least a ratio comment/code > X % The threshold is a parameter and can be changed at will.
Enrich Artifact code with comments
This report lists all Functions with comment/code ratio lower than X % It provides the following information: Function full name, comment/code ratio
Number of JavaScript Functions
Comment/Code ratio
Avoid Artifacts with lines longer than X characters (Javascript/HTML5)
For better readability and portability (printers, terminals, IDE), Artifacts should not have lines longer than X characters.
Avoid Artifacts with lines longer than X characters. The number of characters is a parameter and can be changed at will.
Consider splitting the line.
This report lists all Artifacts with lines longer than X characters. It provides the following information: Artifact full name, number of characters of the longest line.
Number of artifacts
Number of characters
Avoid Artifacts with High Depth of Code (Javascript)
Complex Artifacts are difficult to maintain. Keeping Artifacts small and simple ensures a good readability of the code.

Depth of Code is measured as the maximum number of nested control statements in an artifact. For example, an Artifact that contains an IF statement which contains a While loop which itself contains another IF statement will have a Depth of Code of 3 (at least). Avoid Artifacts with Depth of Code (DoC) greater than X. The threshold level is a parameter that can be changed at will.
Review the design of the Artifact to reduce the Depth of Code
This report lists all Artifacts with a Depth of Code greater than X. It provides the following information: Artifact full name, Depth of code
Number of Artifacts
Depth of code
Avoid direct definition of JavaScript Functions in a Web page (Javascript/HTML5)

Separate behavior from presentation makes the code easier to read and debug, it lets designers and developer work on different files. It allows also to load the JavaScript from the browser one time only (and not each time the file is loaded) if included in the HTML file with the HTML link tag.
All JavaScript Functions should be defined in a JS file and not directly in the Web page (HTM, HTML, JSP).
Best Practices: Implementing JavaScript for rich internet applications http://thinkingandmaking.com/entries/63
This report lists all JavaScript Functions defined within the Web page and not within a JS file. It provides the following information: - Function name - Page name
Number of JavaScript Functions
Page name
Avoid creating cookie without setting httpOnly option (Javascript)

If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

Cross-site scripting attacks often access cookies in an attempt to steal session identifiers or authentication tokens. This is why all major browsers support the HttpOnly cookie property that prevents client-side scripts from accessing the cookie. When HttpOnly is not enabled, attackers may more easily access user cookies.
https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/1004.html https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2013-A6-Sensitive_Data_Exposure https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10-2017_A3-Sensitive_Data_Exposure
document.cookie = "tagname=test";
document.cookie = "tagname=test;HttpOnly";
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JavaScript Functions assigning document.cookie
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using unsecured cookie (Javascript)
The Secure attribute for sensitive cookies in HTTPS sessions is not set, which could cause the user agent to send those cookies in plaintext over an HTTP session.

Cross-site scripting attacks often access cookies in an attempt to steal session identifiers or authentication tokens. This is why all major browsers support the secure cookie property that prevents client-side scripts from accessing the cookie. The Secure attribute for sensitive cookies in HTTPS sessions is not set, which could cause the user agent to send those cookies in plaintext over an HTTP session.
Always setting secure option when creating a cookie
https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/614.html https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2013-A6-Sensitive_Data_Exposure https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10-2017_A3-Sensitive_Data_Exposure
document.cookie = "tagname=test";
document.cookie = "tagname=test;secure";
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JavaScript Functions assigning document.cookie
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid creating cookie with overly broad path (Javascript)

If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

The cookies with an overly broad path, such as the root context path ("/"), can be accessed by all web applications on the same domain name. A cookie with sensitive data, but with too broad a path, could hence be read and tampered by a less secure and untrusted application.
Do not provide a root path
https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/287.html https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2013-A6-Sensitive_Data_Exposure https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10-2017_A3-Sensitive_Data_Exposure
// root path is not recommended document.cookie = "name=test; path=/";
// specifc path is recommended document.cookie = "name=test; path=/admin";
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JavaScript Functions assigning document.cookie
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid having cookie with an overly broad domain (Javascript)

If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

The cookies with an overly broad domain can be accessed by all web applications deployed on this domain and its sub-domains. A cookie with sensitive data, but with too broad a domain, could hence be read and tampered with by a less secure and untrusted application.
Do not provide a domain with wildcard access
https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/287.html https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2013-A6-Sensitive_Data_Exposure https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10-2017_A3-Sensitive_Data_Exposure
// .example.com is not recommended document.cookie = "name=test; domain=.example.com";
// explicit secure.example.com domain is recommended document.cookie = "name=test; domain=secure.example.com";

Always use JSON.parse & JSON.stringify with try/catch block (Javascript)

Ensure that each web service callback is going to be properly checked in order to make sure you will not miss any problem that occurred in your application and you will give the information to the user.

As JSON.parse and JSON.stringify will happen synchronously, we can surround it with a try-catch block. Please note, that you can only do this with synchronous codeblocks, but it won't work for callbacks.
Always use JSON.parse in try/catch block
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/JSON_bad_parse

Number of javascript function using JSON.parse or JSON.stringify
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid hardcoded passwords (Javascript)

Hardcoded passwords in source code should be avoided because they can potentially be retrieved through code inspection and inverse engineering by attackers. Such an attack is difficult to be discovered, and eventually the problem can only be solved at software level thus compromising the usability of the application in the meantime.
This rule identifies variable assignments and function calls and interfaces that include a hardcoded password. This identification is based on password-related semantics.

A non-secure starting patch would be to apply obfuscation techniques to the hardcoded password to prevent reverse-engineering of the generated Python (byte)code. This could be done by hashing the password or constructing the password string in many different places by non-trivial methods. Sensitive data such as passwords should be in principle encrypted and saved in separate files or in a database with restricted user access. Finally one should consider removing backdoors and delegate the password ownership to the end-user.
https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/259.html
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Javascript artifacts
Number of violation occurrences
